Comment: This is one of those heavily-analyzed King's Indian Defense variations.  It is called the Gligoric-Taimanov system in ECO E92.  It often produces very dynamic games with chances for both sides. And the field can shift from queen-side to king-side or can exist on both sides simultaneously.  This game shows how a heavy queen-side attack can shift suddenly to the king-side.
This game is following Matej Sebenic v. Franc Ravnik (Kranj op. 1, 5/7/2004).  Sebenic won that game.

The computer prefers 34. Rxd6 Nxd6 35. Qxd6 Nf8 36. Qxe5 Qd7 37. d6.  But I could only think about a direct assault on the black king now.  Funny how a fixation like that can change the course of a game so much.

In most variations in the computer analysis, 36....Nf8 seems to cover the attack squares that the white queen has.  And the knight being on f6 now sets up a pretty combination.

With this move, black sets up a sequence that can force a perpetual check or, at worst, a pin on the bishop that keeps the bishop tied to the first rank, all to prevent the perpetual check.  So if it succeeds, it can badly compromise the coming attack on black's king.  From now on, I must keep my bishop free to participate in the coming attack.

With this move, black sets up a sequence that can force a perpetual check or, at worst, a pin on the bishop that keeps the bishop tied to the first rank, all to prevent the perpetual check.  So if it succeeds, it can badly compromise the coming attack on black's king.  From now on, I must keep my bishop free to participate in the coming attack.
This sets up the combination which leads to checkmate.  It also entices his queen to play for the perpetual check on the squares e1 and f3.
This sets up the combination which leads to checkmate.  It also entices his queen to play for the perpetual check on the squares e1 and f3.
This sets up the combination which leads to checkmate.  It also entices his queen to play for the perpetual check on the squares e1 and f3.
It seems the only way to stop the coming attack is for him to sacrifice his queen for the bishop with 39...Qxd4.
An 11-move (or shorter) checkmate now commences.  There are some tricks in the coming sequence of checks that are very instructive.

Sloppy play by me (with his king escaping from the checks for just one move) is enough for him to tie up the bishop on g1, starting with ....Qf3+ and then ....Qe1+.  So every check must count now, successfully to drive his king to the "coffin corner." The purpose of 42. Qg6+ is to drive his king to the queen-side for an easy box-in type of mate.

If 42...Kd8, then 43. Bb6+ Ke7 44. Bc5+ Kd8 45. Qf6+, etc.  Yes, I could instead play 43. Qc6+ and pick up his rook, but the mate sequence then disappears and a much longer game ensues.
